title: Logging events with bytes array do not work as expected
body:
When declaring an event with a bytes array parameter, like so;
```
Newgreeting: __log__({_sender: indexed(address), _newgreeting: bytes <= 20})
```

One would expect that when you would log a bytes array value into the log line;
```
@public
@payable
def setGreeting(_greeting: bytes <= 20) -> bool:
    self.greeting = _greeting
    log.Newgreeting( msg.sender, _greeting)
    return True
```

So with ```_greeting = "Hello"``` the expected payload of the event call back argument should be:
```
0x48656c6c6f000000000000000000000000000000
```

The code however returns
```
0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000
```

Setting the log line with a string literal "Hello", so;
```
@public
@payable
def setGreeting(_greeting: bytes <= 20) -> bool:
    self.greeting = _greeting
    log.Newgreeting( msg.sender, "Hello")
    return True
```

results in the right string in the payload of the event call back argument.

Diving a bit deeper into this issue with a ```viper -f ir <filename.v.py>``` call shows that the compiler tries to convert the bytes array into a number of some kind.  This is not expected, one would expect a simple byte-4-byte memory copy from one bytes array to the other.

```
           # Line 16
            [mstore,
              448,
              /* bytearray to number, verify no leading zbytes */
              [with,
                _sub,
                352 <_greeting>,
                [with,
                  _el1,
                  [mload, [add, 32, _sub]],
                  [with,
                    _len,
                    [clamp, 0, [mload, _sub], 32],
                    [seq,
                      [assert, [or, [iszero, _len], [div, _el1, [exp, 256, 31]]]],
                      [div, _el1, [exp, 256, [sub, 3, _len]]]]]]]],
```

>  I guess this is where you insert a cute animal picture ;-)
![Cute Cat picture](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/W-PBFMECvTE/maxresdefault.jpg "Cat in pants")

The problem appears that the String passed as a byte array is seen as a Str value and again converted in a byte array. I expect this to deliver a string that is seen as an empty string and hence padding that empty string with 00 for each byte in the byte array delivers 0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000
